1121801639826874371.text: 9/ Finally, the most upvoted comment in the thread, by far, was this great post from @JaapVergote:https://twitter.com/JaapVergote/status/1118985622528626693 …

1121801424172486656.text: 8/ Content-wise, briefly describe the problem and how you solve it. Ideally mention how you solve it for people just like them or companies just like theirs.

1121801251266547712.text: 7/ Mentioning case study results and logos of customers you work with is effective. Especially if the customers you mention are peers of or similar to the company you're contacting.

1121801083183964160.text: 6/ Skip collateral for the first email, or at most include a one-pager.

1121800789209391105.text: 5/ Be concise. Several comments offered heuristics like "concise enough to be read on a smartphone without scrolling" and "short enough to be read on mobile and responded to quickly."

1121800498749661184.text: 4/ Personalize messages and be authentic. Do as much research as you reasonably can before reaching out to an exec who is super busy.

1121800337721974784.text: 3/ Target people for whom the problem you're solving is a huge, daily pain point. You can also try targeting one level above them ("who on your team should I talk to about this problem?")

1121799938097049600.text: 2/ People reported that multiple channels can work for cold outreach: email, LinkedIn, even cold calling. If one channel doesn't work for a specific target, try another. Be persistent, but not annoying.

1116134443981271040.text: By monopoly, I mean that if there is some subset of customers that can't/won't accept standard terms, then being the only one who is willing to forgo those terms means you'll have zero competition for those customers.

E.g.:
- If your competitors are open 9am-5pm, extended hours provide a monopoly
- If Series A VCs need to own 20%, being okay w/10% provides a monopoly

1115364662273437696.text: The math: assume a Twitter user session lasts 5 min. If you post 15 tweets at 2:30pm, anyone checking Twitter btwn 2:25 & 2:35 will see them. If you post 15 comments over ~15 min, anyone checking Twitter btwn 2:25 & 2:50 will see them. 2.5x the surface area/engagement potential!

1115364206314811392.text: Given one of Twitter's goals is to maximize engagement, I'm surprised at how bad they've made the tweetstorm feature. If you have a 15-comment tweetstorm, Twitter just posts all 15 comments simultaneously. Engagement would be much higher if comments were posted every 1-2 minutes.

1114335848831389697.text: 9/ I'll close by repeating my earlier caveats: I'm trying to be objective but I have a vested interest; this isn't just about Series A/seed investors, but also about seed/pre-seed, growth stage/Series A, etc; & the statements above apply to most Series A firms but not all of 'em.

1114335582212087810.text: 8/ One final thing to consider is that if you choose a seed fund over a Series A fund right now, you can still work with the Series A firm in your next round. If you pick the Series A fund over the seed fund, you won't be able to work with the seed fund on this company.

1114335432878186497.text: 7c/ Also this signaling risk gets worse if you let many Series A firms participate in your seed round. Maybe you can explain away why one firm w/deep pockets didn't step up for your Series A, but it's very hard to explain 2-3 such firms passing when they have insider knowledge.

1114334874968530944.text: 7b/ This signaling risk won't matter if you have A+ traction (because you'll have tons of term sheets) or B traction (because you won't get any term sheets), but can hurt if your traction is a B+ or A-.

1114334684614254592.text: 7a/ Additionally, Series A investors participating in a seed round creates signaling risk. If the fund doesn't lead your Series A, other Series A firms will wonder if there's a reason for that.

1114334339267883008.text: 6/ This is a double-edged sword: you have more capital with similar dilution, and that's great. But you also have a less-involved investor and a higher bar for the next round. Expectations for the next round are proportional to your valuation in this round.

1114334014381252608.text: 5/ Since Series A investors don't care about seed returns, they'll offer nicer terms. A seed fund might offer $1m at a $10m valuation while a Series A fund offers $1m at a $15m valaution. The Series A fund doesn't care about $10m vs $15m, they just want to do your whole Series A.

1114333687993081858.text: 4b/ If you do let next round's investors invest today, you want the check size to be meaningful to them. E.g. if a Series A fund normally invests $10m and they invest $1m in your round, that sucks; if they normally invest $4m and they invest $2m in your round, that's okay.

1114333434002853888.text: 4a/ Series A investors won't spend as much time w/you as w/their Series A companies. This is basic incentives: if they invested $1m in your co & $10m in another co, you have about 1/10 of the priority of the other co. Especially true if the investor is already overworked.

1114332887669547008.text: 3/ Series A investors typically invest in seed rounds because they want to improve their shot of investing in your Series A. They don't care about the seed investment's performance itself. This isn't true 100% of the time, but probably 80-90% of the time.

1114332651509280768.text: 2/ As a caveat, I have a vested interest because I don't like competing against Series A investors in seed rounds :). In the rest of this thread I'll talk about Series A firms investing at seed, but it's a placeholder for Stage N+1 firms investing at Stage N.

1083767535453892608.text: 8/ There are other examples, but the key is that each of these compounding moats continues to strengthen your position over time. So maybe in Year 2 it costs someone $10m to compete w/you, but in Year 5 it's $300m, and in Year 10 it's billions. That's a great position to be in.

1083766932027760640.text: 7/ Product ecosystem: as you develop more interdependencies and relationships between your product and other products that your customers use, your product gains momentum as the "default option" and switching costs rise dramatically.

1083766489021202437.text: 6/ Locking up scarce resources and distribution channels: as you sell more product, you build up more clout to carve out exclusive agreements (thereby locking out competitors).

1083766037361786880.text: 5/ Brand: as you sell more product and continue to meet/beat customer expectations, your brand becomes stronger and stronger.

1083765768775335936.text: 4/ Data network effects: as you sell more product, you accumulate more data for improving and differentiating your product from other solutions in the market.

1083765579016679424.text: 3/ Network effects: as you sell more product, the product becomes more valuable to your users.

1083765385193709568.text: 2/ Economies of scale: as you sell more product, your per-unit costs continue to drop.

1083765159988932608.text: 1/ The more I think about moats (sustainable competitive advantages), the more interested I become in "compounding moats," which are competitive advantages that get stronger as your company grows. 1068545138035585024.text:
Revenue multiples compress as startups grow:

Seed: $0 ARR, $8m valuation -> infinite multiple
Series A: $1.5m ARR, $30m val -> 20x
Series B: $7m ARR, $105m val -> 15x
..
IPO: $200m ARR, $1.6b val -> 8x

Painful implication: 3x-5x revenue growth often results in a 2x-3x markup.

The costs of ballot initiatives should be described in per capita numbers, not absolute numbers.

Bad: "this project will cost $8b."
Good: "this project will cost the average taxpayer $3k over two years."

"Is this worth $8b?" is very different from "would you pay $3k for this?"

1039710614338203648.text: 7/ The WHEN also varies. If an investor loves products, then when would they believe your product will be a winner? For some it can be an idea on a napkin. For others it's a prototype, or a launched MVP, or a product w/heavy traction. Some ppl are more conservative than others.

1039710244312502278.text: 6b/ (Hat tip to @nabeel for pointing this out to me a few years ago.)

1039709979081465856.text: 6/ The preference for one of these three attribute typically leads to each investor's greatest hits & biggest misses. E.g. a VC who overweighs teams will make "genius" bets in teams w/o an idea that end up succeeding, and also "dumb" bets in teams w/bad ideas that end up failing.

1039709682837774338.text: 5/ Investors care about all of these things, but usually really care about one of them over the other two. So if a VC is focused on finding the best teams, they are going to be hard to sway with a huge market or a great product -- unless those things also come with a strong team.

1039709406655463424.text: 4/ The three main WHATs are the Product (product idea, traction, engagement, etc), the Market (market size, market growth, severity of problem, etc), and the Team (prior achievements, perceived ability to execute, founder/market fit, etc).

1039709106162958337.text: 3/ Investors, in general, vary greatly in a) WHAT makes them believe and b) WHEN they're able to believe.

1039708959433617408.text: 2/ The earlier you are willing to believe, the smarter you look when you're right, and the sillier you look when you're wrong.

IMHO "capital efficiency" should describe companies that get an outsized amount done w/their funds.

If others need $4m to do what you did w/$2m, you're capital efficient.

If others need $200k to do what you did w/$500k, you're not capital efficient (despite using less capital).

"Month-over-month growth since launch" is a BS metric.

Example of 6 mo of growth:
$1000 to $100k -> 115%/mo growth!
$100 to $100k -> 216%/mo growth!
$10 to $100k -> 364%/mo growth!

First month revenue is trivial in absolute terms but has outsided impact on this (worthless) KPI.

1017206261526327296.text:
There's often a ton of value in plugging the biggest bottleneck in a company.

Example: a company has 12 engs, 2 marketers, 6 salespeople, & 5 misc employees. If there are too few leads or too few AEs, you can often 2x new sales by growing the 25-person co by 2-3 employees (10%).

1016861251731771392.text:
People often view fundraising as a distraction, but it's healthier to view it as super high leverage activity.

1) If it takes 200 meetings to raise $8m, that's $40k per hour of work.

2) If you can raise $10m instead of $8m, that's 10 extra people you can hire for your company.

Tips for getting good investors to say Yes:
- Have a good story for a possible path to 50x+
